I actually have two problems with this code:

  1. What I am trying to do is get the robot to spin it‚Äôs arm mechanism if the beam break is broken. the code builds but I cannot deploy it because I think, since I am calling the armsubsystem from the BeamBreak subsystem the RIO log is telling me I am trying to create a new SPARKmax which has already been created. My most recent attempt was to use a getter method to get an instance of the subsystem from the Robot Container file. I‚Äôm not sure what the correct way to do this is or if I should go about it differently.
  2. I then tried to create an LED subsystem and was using the WPIlib to help me use AddressableLEDs, but I didn‚Äôt get far as I am getting a build error here with my {} brackets and I‚Äôm not sure what I‚Äôm doing wrong?

Why does the beam break have its own subsystem?

Sounds like it should be part of the Arm.

To get any detailed/specific help you are going to need to post a link to the code.

What is the beambreak used for? I agree with @jdaming that it should probably just be part of something else (likely arm).

Also, this isn‚Äôt going to do what you want: Brainboard4925/subsystems/BeamBreak.java at main ¬∑ TheResistance4925/Brainboard4925 ¬∑ GitHub. You shouldn‚Äôt be instantiating commands in your subsystems except as a factory method to return the command. Simply creating the object like this will not schedule it, so it won‚Äôt actually run

This is a test board I have the beam break connected to right now. Once we get it attached to our competition robot, we‚Äôd like it to turn the LED‚Äôs to say‚Ä¶green, so that the driver knows we have obtained a game piece with the intake. Possible also stow the intake. When I started with the test board, it only had an arm. I can read the voltage from the beam break fine, but any command I try to run from it hasn‚Äôt worked. At one point, I did move the beam break do the arm subsystem, but that didn‚Äôt work for me either. What do you mean by ‚ÄúYou shouldn‚Äôt be instantiating commands in your subsystems except as a factory method to return the command‚Äù - where should I put the command?

I think you may be confusing Java methods and ‚Äúrobot commands‚Äù. I suggest you read up some here:

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Command-Based Programming

This sequence of articles serves as an introduction to and reference for the WPILib command-based framework. For a collection of example projects using the command-based framework, see Command-Base...

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2024-01-25T04:11:47.287Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":280,"readers_count":279,"score":91.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":451945,"topic_slug":"java-how-do-i-call-a-subsystem-from-another-subsystem","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/commandbased/index.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Command-Based Programming ‚Äî FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":23}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":35842,"username":"4925TheResistance","name":"Jim","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/4/ecae2f/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36169,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/java-how-do-i-call-a-subsystem-from-another-subsystem/451945/6","custom_user_title":"Software Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3293989,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-25T04:23:29.248Z","cooked":"

It‚Äôs your choice how you want to organize your project. However, a subsystem is a logical grouping of related hardware (e.g. sensors and actuators), and commands are generally discrete things you can do with that hardware. You‚Äôll have to decide what‚Äôs related enough to be grouped together. We don‚Äôt know what your robot design is, so it‚Äôs hard to make specific recommendations.

Let‚Äôs assume for a moment that your LEDs are used purely by your arm to signal that a note has been picked up, and the beambreak is the sensor used to detect a note. This likely isn‚Äôt far from the truth.

I would have a single ‚ÄúArmSubsystem‚Äù that contains the LED stuff, the beambreak stuff, and any motors or whatever else is necessary for the arm to work as designed. Then I would define commands to set the LED output (whether on/off, or color-changing, or a pattern if addressable), and to control the motors.

4925TheResistance:

What do you mean by ‚ÄúYou shouldn‚Äôt be instantiating commands in your subsystems except as a factory method to return the command‚Äù - where should I put the command?

The older paradigm is to have discrete command classes, so that‚Äôs one way to do it. A more modern approach is to define commands functionally via lambdas. The most recent approach is to define methods on your subsystem that return command objects. This is a form of factory pattern that allows your commands to natively access subsystem functionality without exposing it through a bunch of subsystem methods. The wpilib docs and example projects show all of these options.

But yes, as @Hollisms suggested, you should give the docs a read-through.

I have been through the Command Based Programming section of the WPIlib a few times, and between that and the Zero to Autonomous Youtube series - I have found them both really helpful. Problem with sensors and and LEDs is that the help in WPIib is written for Timed Robot, so I"m not sure how to structure it. What if I write a command for the if-then statement part of what I‚Äôm trying to do with the beam break? Then I think I could require more than one subsystem? I‚Äôm not sure how to structure that though

You can do this by following this example:

In my case these are my intake classes if it helps

package frc.robot.subsystens;

import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.motorcontrol.PWMSparkMax;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.SubsystemBase;
import frc.robot.Contants.MotorPorst;

public class Intake extends SubsystemBase {

  private final PWMSparkMax intake = 
    new PWMSparkMax(MotorPorst.motorIntake);

  public void setSpeed(double speed) {
    intake.set(speed);
  }
  
 public void stopintake() {
    intake.set(0);
  }
}

package frc.robot.commands.teleop;

import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj.Joystick;
import edu.wpi.first.wpilibj2.command.CommandBase;
import frc.robot.Contants.Axis;
import frc.robot.Contants.Joysticks;
import frc.robot.Contants.MotorSpeeds;
import frc.robot.subsystens.Intake;

public class intakeCommand extends CommandBase {
  private final Joystick shooterStick = new Joystick(Joysticks.shooterStick);
  Intake m_IntakeSubsystem;

  public intakeCommand(Intake driveSubsystem) {
    m_IntakeSubsystem = driveSubsystem;

    addRequirements(m_IntakeSubsystem);
  }

  @Override
  public void initialize() {}

  @Override
  public void execute() {
    if (shooterStick.getRawAxis(Axis.leftTrigger) != 0) {
      m_IntakeSubsystem.setSpeed(shooterStick.getRawAxis(Axis.leftTrigger) * MotorSpeeds.intakeSpeed);
    } else if (shooterStick.getRawAxis(Axis.rightTrigger) != 0) {
      m_IntakeSubsystem.setSpeed(-shooterStick.getRawAxis(Axis.rightTrigger) * MotorSpeeds.intakeSpeed);
    } else {
      m_IntakeSubsystem.setSpeed(0);
    }
  }

  @Override
  public boolean isFinished() {
    return false;
  }
  
}

In your BeamBreak subsystem you would create a method something like:

public boolean  isBeamBroken() {
  if (m_sensor => kThreshold) {
    return true;
  } else { 
    return false;
}

Then in your command you would call the above doing something like:

public void execute() {
  If (m_Arm.isBeamBroken() {
    m_Arm.startMotor();
    m_isFinished = true;
  }
}

Then you would associate the command with a joystick button or make it part of a command sequence that is the default command for the subsystem.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":25,"updated_at":"2024-01-25T13:43:26.253Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":161,"readers_count":160,"score":47.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":451945,"topic_slug":"java-how-do-i-call-a-subsystem-from-another-subsystem","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":60531,"username":"NKRY_FRC","name":"Krypton #9487","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nkry_frc/{size}/206723_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":36169,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/java-how-do-i-call-a-subsystem-from-another-subsystem/451945/10","custom_user_title":"Software Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3294222,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-25T15:21:06.056Z","cooked":"

To expand on @Hollisms example. You could also bind the isBeamBroken() method to a Trigger object and use that to trigger the command like so:

Trigger m_beamBreakTrigger = new Trigger(()->m_beamBreakSubsystem.isBeamBroken());
m_beamBreakTrigger.onTrue(new StartMotorCommand(m_armSubsystem));

Though I‚Äôd actually recommend also looking into Command Factories so your command binding would look more something like:

m_beamBreakTrigger.onTrue(m_armSubsystem.startMotorCommand())

I‚Äôd also probably personally combine the beam break sensor into whatever subsystem it is more adjacent to. Assuming the beam break sensor is on your Intake and detecting a Note incoming I‚Äôd include it in your Intake subsystem, add the isBeamBroken() method or similar, and then use it to trigger the command on the Arm Subsystem. So this would look like:

Trigger m_beamBreak = new Trigger(()->m_intake.isBeamBroken());
m_beamBreak.onTrue(m_arm.startMotorCommand());

You could also possibly setup the Trigger object also in your subsystem, then access it through your RobotContainer, leading to

m_intake.beamBreakTrigger().onTrue(m_arm.startMotorCommand());

Which I think is pretty cool as it minimizes the logic at the top level, and very clearly shows that an action in one subsystem is triggering the other.

Hope some of these suggestions/examples help.

Nice progression of thinking. Nobody ever said the simplest solution is the easiest to find. But‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm optimistic that if I can just get the students to write out what they want to accomplish they may find that the succinct code you wrote at the end can be gotten to directly. [Again they sat down in front of VSC and started typing their extends CommandBase [with deprecated error] then asked what do we want? Sigh.]

ExploitSage:

You could also possibly setup the Trigger object also in your subsystem, then access it through your RobotContainer, leading to

m_intake.beamBreakTrigger().onTrue(m_arm.startMotorCommand());

Which I think is pretty cool as it minimizes the logic at the top level, and very clearly shows that an action in one subsystem is triggering the other.

I like this solution, so I am trying to implement it. The code deploys now, but doesn‚Äôt work. The beam break doesn‚Äôt start the motor when broken. I think my mistake is in this part of the command: the intellisense underlines ‚ÄúisBeamBroken‚Äù in the
private boolean isBeamBroken; line and says The value of the field BeamCommand.isBeamBroken is not usedJava(570425421)

public class BeamCommand extends Command {
private final ArmSubsystem m_armSubsystem;
private final BeamBreak m_beamBreak;
private boolean isBeamBroken;

public BeamCommand(ArmSubsystem m_armSubsystem, BeamBreak m_beamBreak, double propellorSpeed, boolean isBeamBroken) {
    this.m_armSubsystem = m_armSubsystem;
    this.m_beamBreak = m_beamBreak;
    this.isBeamBroken = isBeamBroken;
    addRequirements(m_armSubsystem);
    addRequirements(m_beamBreak);

Assuming OP is actually headed toward an Intake subsystem that should own the beam break sensor because it uses it to turn off (otherwise @jdaming is right and all this should be in Arm), I think this is your and lint programs preference:

In Intake:
public final Trigger m_beamBreak = new Trigger(this::isBeamBroken);

In RobotContainer:
m_intake.beamBreak.onTrue(m_arm::startMotor);

I also hound the students to wordsmith the phrase beamBreak to more like objectInPosition

the intellisense underlines ‚ÄúisBeamBroken‚Äù in the

I agree with @Fletch1373 on the error message being both correct and ignorable. Once you have it working you should consider cleaning it up.

And @SLAB-Mr.Thomas is spot on. For testing purposes, map the BeamCommand to a button on the joystick.

Once you have that working try making it the default command on your arm/beam break subsystem or probably better follow the trigger pattern mentioned by @ExploitSage.

Then‚Ä¶. Consider merging the 2 subsystems.

SLAB-Mr.Thomas:

I also hound the students to wordsmith the phrase beamBreak to more like objectInPosition

Absolutely. Keeping names as close to the problem-space as possible (instead of the solution-space) is one of the most important principles in writing good code.

P.S. I personally detest hungarian notation (i.e. m_), especially for members that are part of an object‚Äôs public interface, but the WPILib standard is what it is.

Edit: WPILib standard allows omitting m_ on public fields, per @Peter_Johnson.
